channel.title: Basic Electronics Terms/Elements
channel.description:
[center][img]http://img216.imageshack.us/img216/8782/cktel.gif[/img][/center]
Obviously I didn't define these terms, but I think it would be a good idea to have them here for reference.
[b]Volt[/b] - the unit of electromotive force, the measure of electrical pressure, is abbreviated v or V, and voltage is represented by I. The voltage (of a circuit) is the effective (greatest root-mean-square) difference of potential between any two conductors of the circuit concerned. Some systems, such as 3-phase 4-wire and single-phase 3-wire may have multiple circuits of differing voltages. The Nominal Voltage is the value assigned to a circuit to conveniently designate its voltage class (e.g. 120 volts, 240 volts, 480 volts). The actual voltage of the circuit can vary.
[b]Amp[/b] - or Ampere, the unit of intensity of electrical current (the measure of electrical flow), is abbreviated a or A.
[b]Watt[/b] - the unit of power or rate of work represented by a current of one ampere under a pressure of one volt (abbreviated w or W). The English horsepower is approximately equal to 846 watts. Wattage ratings of lamps actually measure the power consumption not the illuminating capability.
[b]Ohm[/b] - the unit of electrical resistance and impedance, abbreviated with the symbol omega, W. Resistance is the opposition offered by a substance to the passage of electrical current. Impedance is the apparent resistance in a circuit to the flow of alternating current.
[b]AC and DC[/b] - Abbreviations for alternating current and direct current respectively.
[b]Current[/b] - a movement of electricity analogous to the flow of a stream of water.
[b]Direct Current[/b] - An electric current flowing in one direction only (i.e. current produced using a battery).
[b]Alternating Current[/b] - a periodic electric current that reverses its direction at regular intervals.
[b]Ohm's Law[/b] (E=IR) [b]Power Formula[/b] (P=IE)
[u]Symbol:[/u] [u]Measured in:[/u] [u]Description:[/u] [code] P - Power W - Watts Electrical push E - Electromotive Force V - Volts Electrical pressure I - Current (Ioda) A - Amperes Electrical current R - Resistance Ohms Electrical resistance [/code]
...more to come

item.title: Basic Electronics Terms/Elements
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

T4_:

Amp - or Ampere, the unit of intensity of electrical current (the measure of electrical flow), is abbreviated a or A.

The Ampere is not a measurement of the ‘intensity’ of current, it’s the rate of transfer of electrical charge in coulombs per second.

T4_:

Ohm - the unit of electrical resistance and impedance, abbreviated with the symbol omega, W. Resistance is the opposition offered by a substance to the passage of electrical current. Impedance is the apparent resistance in a circuit to the flow of alternating current.

I didn’t know the greek letter omega could be written as W, I’ve only ever seen Ω used. Are you sure this is correct?

I’d like to know where you got this information from, because as newbiehacker says - a lot of this is wrong and inaccurate. Allowing it to be posted and stickied here because there is no good alternative is a pretty lame excuse. People who do not understand the fundamentals of electricity/electronics may be confused and mislead by this.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Electronics Terms/Elements
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“newbiehacker, post:19, topic:290037”]Problems with this thread:

[ul][li]Direct Current does not necessarily come from a battery, it can be rectified AC.[/li]
[li]AC doesn’t change direction periodically, it’s sinusoidal as a function of the way it is produced.[/li]
[li][quote author=T4_ link=topic=383396.msg2878289#msg2878289 date=1248179361]
Volt - the unit of electromotive force, the measure of electrical pressure, is abbreviated v or V, and voltage is represented by I. The voltage (of a circuit) is the effective (greatest root-mean-square) difference of potential between any two conductors of the circuit concerned. Some systems, such as 3-phase 4-wire and single-phase 3-wire may have multiple circuits of differing voltages. The Nominal Voltage is the value assigned to a circuit to conveniently designate its voltage class (e.g. 120 volts, 240 volts, 480 volts). The actual voltage of the circuit can vary.
[/quote]
Voltage isn’t epresented by I, V = IR, you even wrote this equation yourself (obv copypasta)[/li]
[li]You put Amps and Current, current is measured in amps, they are the same thing (some more copypasta fail)[/li][/ul]

I think this thread should be removed until someone who actually knows what they’re posting posts.[/quote]

I think you should do it then!

Read full topic

Some systems, such as 3-phase 4-wire and single-phase 3-wire may have multiple circuits of differing voltages. The Nominal Voltage is the value assigned to a circuit to conveniently designate its voltage class (e.g. 120 volts, 240 volts, 480 volts). The actual voltage of the circuit can vary.[/quote]
Voltage isn’t epresented by I, V = IR, you even wrote this equation yourself (obv copypasta)[/li]

item.title: Basic Electronics Terms/Elements
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

you missed a lot of basic terms such as diodes, transistors, zener diodes, relays (Although they’re not used so much), sr bistables, 555 timers, ic’s, inductors, how electromotive force actually works (positive being attracted towards negative and electron flowing being the reverse of conventional flow), multiplexing is a useful tool, logic families, etc. etc. etc.

Edit: also, they’re called components, not elements

Read full topic
